title: Understanding Piano Notes
content:
Let's start by understanding the layout of a piano. The keyboard is made up of repeating patterns of white and black keys.
  • The white keys are labeled A through G, and once you reach G, the pattern starts over at A.
  • The black keys sit in groups of twos and threes and don't have unique letter names. Instead, each black key is named based on the white key it's next to:
    • If you go up from a white key, the black key is called a sharp (♯)
    • If you go down, it's called a flat (♭)
  • For example:
    • The black key between C and D can be called C♯ or D♭
    • They're the same note, just named differently depending on the musical context
Before we can build chords, we need to start with a scale—a group of notes played in order, step by step. Think of it like a musical staircase.

The easiest place to begin is with the C Major scale, which uses only white keys:
C – D – E – F – G – A – B – C

Click on the button to see the C major scale!

title: Understanding Intervals
content:
An interval is the distance between two notes on the piano. The smallest possible interval is called a half step—that's when you go from one key to the very next key, whether it's white or black. A whole step is simply two half steps.

You'll need to understand intervals to build chords, because the spacing between notes (not just the notes themselves) is what gives chords their emotional character.

title: Major vs Minor: The Emotional Color of Music
content:
One small change in a chord can make a big difference in how it feels and change a song's tone.
In music, that change often comes down to whether a chord is major or minor.

  • Major chords in songs like 'Dancing Queen' and 'Don't Stop Believin' typically sound happy, bright, or resolved.
  • Minor chords in songs like 'Bad Romance' and 'Fix You' tend to sound more sad, introspective, or tense.
To hear how this works in practice, let's listen to the same melody—'A Whole New World' from Aladdin—played in both a major and a minor key.

title: Building Chords
content:
A chord is created by playing multiple notes together. The most common type of chord is a triad, made up of three notes:
  1. The root – the starting note
  2. The third – this defines whether the chord is major or minor
  3. The fifth – adds stability and fullness
The key difference between major and minor chords lies in the type of third used:
  • A major chord has a major third, which is 4 half steps above the root
  • A minor chord has a minor third, which is 3 half steps above the root
  • The fifth is always 7 half steps above the root in both major and minor chords
Let's take a closer look using the C major and C minor chords:

C Major:
C (root) → E (major third, 4 half steps above C) → G (fifth, 7 half steps above C)

C Minor:
C (root) → E♭ (minor third, 3 half steps above C) → G (fifth, 7 half steps above C)

The only difference is the middle note—E in C major becomes E♭ in C minor. But that small shift creates a completely different sound.

title: Build Your Own Chords
content:
Now it's your turn! Let's practice building both major and minor chords using the same root note.

Try to build these two chords:
  • G Major chord:
    • G (root)
    • B (major third, 4 half steps from root)
    • D (fifth, 7 half steps from root)
  • G Minor chord:
    • G (root)
    • B♭ (minor third, 3 half steps from root)
    • D (fifth, 7 half steps from root)
Notice that the only difference is the third note: B for major versus B♭ for minor. The fifth is always 7 half steps above the root in both major and minor chords.

Click the piano keys to select your notes, then press the Check Chord button to see if you've built it correctly!

title: Build Taylor Swift's Chord Progression
content:
One of the most popular chord progressions in Taylor Swift's music is:

G major → D major → A minor → C major

This sequence appears in several of her biggest hits, including 'Love Story,' 'You Belong With Me,' and 'Fearless.'

Before we see these chords in action, let's practice building each one. Use what you've learned about root, third, and fifth to construct the full triad.

Click the keys on the keyboard to select your notes. Once you've chosen all three, click 'Check' to see if you got it right!

content: Now that you've successfully built all the chords in one of Taylor Swift's go-to progressions—G major, D major, A minor, and C major—it's time to see them in action. As the video plays, click the button for each chord when prompted to follow along.

content: Beyoncé's hit song 'Halo' uses a beautiful chord progression that creates its emotional atmosphere.
